qas.question: White LEDs can be made by coating what?
What are near-ultraviolet LEDs coated with to create white LED?

answers.text: copper and aluminium-doped zinc sulfide (ZnS:Cu, Al)

qas.question: What device also works in a similar way as NUV LEDs?
The method of coating NUVs less efficient than what other LEDs?
What light can harm human eyes or skin?
White LEDs can be made by not coating what?
What are non-near-ultraviolet LEDs coated with to create white LED?
What device also works in a similar way as non-NUV LEDs?
The method of coating NUVs more efficient than what other LEDs?

context: White LEDs can also be made by coating <a0_0><b5_0>near-ultraviolet (NUV)<b5_0/> LEDs<a0_0/> with a mixture of high-efficiency europium-based phosphors that emit red and blue, plus <a1_0><b6_0>copper and aluminium-doped zinc sulfide<b6_0/> (ZnS:Cu, Al)<a1_0/> that emits green. This is a method analogous to the way <a2_0><b7_0>fluorescent lamps<b7_0/><a2_0/> work. This method is less efficient than <a3_0>blue<a3_0/> LEDs with YAG:Ce phosphor, as the Stokes shift is larger, so more energy is converted to heat, but yields light with better spectral characteristics, which render color better. Due to the higher radiative output of the ultraviolet LEDs than of the <b8_0>blue<b8_0/> ones, both methods offer comparable brightness. A concern is that <a4_0>UV light<a4_0/> may leak from a malfunctioning light source and cause harm to human eyes or skin.
